Wrapping up this week with some teacher celebrations. Over the past several weeks, two KSD teachers earned their doctorate:

Dr. Ashley Crannage, 2nd grade teacher at Westchester Elementary, earned an Educational Doctorate Degree from Maryville University. Her capstone project was: “Using Self-Assessment to Increase Student Performance With Special Reference to Reading”.

Dr. Jessica Doneff, English Language Arts teacher at Kirkwood High School, earned her doctorate degree from Maryville University in May 2020. Her dissertation was titled "An Alternative Approach to the Traditional Classroom".

Congrats to both, and thank you for everything you do for the students!

Thank you to @NipherMiddle teacher Jenn Sievers for sharing her teaching and parenting lens for some great tips for families. In the article, the tips she shares include:

“Create a working schedule for your family. Teachers realize all families are different, and not everyone can fit into one mold. Make sure you develop the best plan for your family and communicate that with the teachers if need be. Planners or monthly calendar boards are helpful. A set wake-up time and morning routine will help with the transition to learning time. The more predictable the day, the less stressed your family will be.”

To read the full story, please visit: https://www.laduenews.com/front-and-center/family/local-educators-share-advice-for-students-and-parents-navigating-e-learning/article_8bd2fd88-65af-5229-806f-08258b1ad81b.html

post_text: Congrats to two KHS juniors, Avery Chase and Claire Beck. Their essays were recognized in the YES! Magazine spring writing contest!
shared_text:
Kirkwood High School
June 16 at 4:04 PM ·

Great news still rolling in for our students....For the spring 2020 YES! Magazine student writing contest, students read the article “Alicia Garza: How to Prepare for 2020” by Kate Werning. After reading the article, students responded to a writing prompt that they might accomplish in their wildest dreams for themselves or for this nation—and the steps they would take to make this vision a reality.

From the hundreds of essays written, Kirkwood High School junior Avery Chase’s essay titled “In My Eyes” was recognized as a “Powerful Voice Winner” in the high school category. Claire Beck’s essay earned a “Literary Gem,” which means an excerpt of her essay is published on the YES! Magazine website.
For more information on the contest, please visit the YES! Magazine website: https://www.yesmagazine.org/yes-for-teacher/seven-brilliant-student-essays-on-your-wildest-dreams-for-2020/#litgems

Students from both middle schools competed in a Virtual Battle of the Books. The teams were set to compete at the area-wide competition, but the event was canceled.

A photo of her artwork was selected to represent District 15 in Missouri Art Education Association/ Missouri Alliance for Arts Education (MAEA/MAAE) Missouri Senate Art Competition. For the competition, student artwork images were submitted and organized by the 34 districts in Missouri. Each district selected one student artwork and the artwork is framed and displayed throughout the year at the Missouri Capitol to advocate legislator support for the arts. District 15 Senator Andrew Koening and representatives from MAAE and MAEA selected Rory’s art the winning piece to represent this part of Missouri. For receiving this honor, Rory was invited to participate in a celebration at the Missouri state capitol and at the annual spring Missouri Art Educator’s Conference. These events were canceled in light of the coronavirus health concerns. A medal presentation will be scheduled for a later date.

Today is "Favorite Book Day". Dr. Condon loves to read the book “Corduroy”. Please share your favorite book with us here!
"I used to read this book to my children when they were little, and now I love reading it to my grandchildren. I love this book so much because it reminds me of when I was little girl. My mom used to take me to the department store to buy our new school clothes each year. I looked forward to that trip to the department store every year. I loved riding on the escalator and looking at all the candy and cookies through the glass counters. I hope you enjoy this book as much as I do." #KSDConnects

What started off as a $1,000 donation in food from Splunk inspired Schnucks to donate over 2,000 pounds of food to our canned food drive! Students Keysor Elementary School and @NorthKirkwoodMiddleSchool used their engineering, design and creative thinking skills to collaborate on food-themed structures.

Over Robinson Elementary School, the Kirkwood Fire Department and @kirkwoodmoms dropped off turkeys for the Robinson pantry.

Other schools actively hosted canned food drives, several challenging Webster Groves schools to see who can collect the most.

Items collected are going to pantries including KirkCare, #KSDNOW, and to other local families in need.

During this season on thanks, we are thankful for our community! #onekirkwood

Congrats again, Joe. And thank you to ALL bus drivers who support our students!
